choices.B: The backups would be possible only if the database is running in ARCHIVELOG mode.
choices.C: The backups need to be restored and the database has to be recovered in case of a media failure.
choices.E: The backups by default consist of all the data blocks within the chosen files or the full database.

comments.content: I circled back to this because I was not certain I was correct. I verified with Oracle DB and you are correct. I should have paid more attention. Thanks.
If database is open then backup with RMAN can only be done when database is in archivelog mode. Question says database is in open mode.
A is not correct as the database must be shut down for backups to be consistent. The question states that the database is open.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CDE
Why would B be correct? Backups using RMAN are in fact possible with the database in noarchivelog mode. However, the backups would be cold (offline) backups. We would only be able to restore the DB to the most previous backup but we can in fact take the backup.

questions.question_text:
You are managing an Oracle Database 12c database. The database is open, and you plan to perform Recovery Manager (RMAN) backups.
Which three statements are true about these backups? (Choose three.)
Which three tools or tasks are run by default as part automated maintenance tasks? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
A direct upgrade is one where either the Database Upgrade Assistant (DBUA) or command-line
upgrade script is used to upgrade your database to Oracle Database 12c. Direct upgrade is supported when the source database is running version 10.2.0.5+.
For lower versions:
1. Original export/import (min version 5)
2.Transportable Tablespaces (min version 8.1.5)
3.upgrade to 10.5 and then direct upgrade.

https://www.oracle.com/technetwork/database/upgrade/upgrading-oracle-database-wp-12c-1896123.pdf

i think CE
because Datapump (expdp,impdp ) doesn't exist in oracle 9i.

comments.content:
Datapump did exist in Oracle 9i though the usable tools were exp and imp. Technically, we would need to export using 9i exp and import using 12c imp to migrate from 9i to 12c.

Expd and impdp became available starting Oracle 10g, which are more widely used now due to enhanced performance.

questions.question_text:
You plan to upgrade your Oracle Database 9i to Oracle Database 12c.
Which two methods can you use? (Choose two.)

choices.C: Perform a direct upgrade by manually running the catctl.pl and catupgrd.sql scripts before issuing the STARTUPUPGRADE command.
choices.D: Install the Oracle Database 12c software, create a new Oracle 12c database, and then use the Oracle Data Pump to import data from the source Oracle 9i database to the target Oracle 12c database.
choices.B: Perform a direct upgrade by running the Database Upgrade Assistant (DBUA).
choices.E: Upgrade your current database to Oracle Database release 10.2.0.5, and then upgrade to Oracle Database 12c.

choices.B: Automatic statistics collection is stopped for the CUSTOMERS table.
choices.C: Statistics for the CUSTOMERS table are locked and cannot be overwritten.
choices.D: Statistics subsequently gathered on the CUSTOMERS table are stored as pending statistics.
choices.A: Existing statistics for the CUSTOMERS table become unusable for the query optimizer.

choices.B: It ensures that all dirty buffers are written to data files during consistent shutdown.
choices.E: It prompts the Database Writer (DBWn) process to write checkpoint information into data file headers and the control file.
choices.D: Frequent thread checkpoints can degrade database performance.
choices.C: It reduces the time required for recovery in case of an instance failure.
choices.A: It prompts the Checkpoint (CKPT) process to write data to the data files and redo information to the online redo log files.

discussion.content:
It is B,C,D
E cannot be because the Database Writer (DBWn) process don't write checkpoint information into data file headers and the control file.

A and E are incorrect.
CKPT itslef does not write data to datafiles. CKPT updates the control file and data file headers with checkpoint information and signals DBWn to write blocks to disk.

comments.content: No it is really BCD finally
